description: Borrowed from Late Latin internecīnus (“deadly”), from inter (“between”) and necō (“to kill”).

entries.meaning: Mutually destructive; most often applied to warfare.
examples: Internecine strife in Gaza claimed its most senior victim yesterday.

entries.meaning: Characterized by struggle within a group, usually applied to an ethnic or familial relationship.
examples: The Mongol people were plagued by internecine conflict until Genghis Khan unified them.
